title: Submarine program hits six-month delay
text:
During questioning, Senator Patrick clashed with Defence Minister Linda Reynolds after he quipped "all is well in the Soviet state" in frustration over the answers he was getting from officials.

"This is a project running late minister and if you don't recognise that you shouldn't be in the chair," Senator Patrick said.

French shipbuilder Naval Group was selected in April 2016 to design 12 new submarines under a $50 billion program to replace the Collins class boats.

However, the project has faced heavy scrutiny over concerns French suppliers are being favoured at the expense of Australian companies, while contract negotiations between the Commonwealth and Naval Group have been plagued by disagreements for months.

Estimates also heard that a further 220 workers at the taxpayer-owned shipbuilder ASC are facing uncertainty over their jobs by the end of March despite the government's $90 billion commitment to build warships in Australia.

That would bring the number of workers shed at ASC since 2017 to 800, sparking accusations from Labor that the government has failed to bridge the so-called valley of death of job losses in the shipbuilding industry.

The government has argued Labor's failure under Kevin Rudd and Julia Gillard to commission the construction of a new ship in Australia led to the lack of work for ship builders, resulting in redundancies.

Meanwhile, a senior Defence executive maintained he acted in good faith after being questioned over his role in awarding a contract worth almost $400,000 to a company where his son works part-time.

Defence's chief information officer Stephen Pearson awarded a contract to Victorian consultancy firm Sinapse through a "limited tender" to conduct a review for the department instead of conducting a competitive process.

Mr Pearson failed to declare to colleagues his son did part-time work for the company but told estimates his son "did not receive any benefit from this engagement, if that helps".

Under questioning from Labor Senate leader Penny Wong, Mr Pearson conceded he had made a mistake.

"On reflection, yes, I think there was a chance of a perceived conflict of interest, I do acknowledge that."
description: Senate estimates hears of the latest problem on the $50 billion project, while more job losses in the shipbuilding industry have been revealed.
